pros: nice people to work with

pros: Haven't worked here long but so far seems they care about employees and work environment isn't tense like your typical call center. No work from home which is fine, I like interacting with my co-workers.They provide free food/snacks daily as well as coffee and beverages.
cons: Honestly only disadvantage is the benefits package. You accrue time per pay period and you are penalized for using your sick time. I would recommend allowing employees to use sick time they have and only pentalize or give an occurence if they are out of time and call in sick. Also you should trust your employees. Most companies provide their employees their vacation allotment up front to plan out vacation year. Also 3 weeks vacation isnt competitive, every bank i worked for previously gave 4 weeks vacation with the option to purchase a additional week.overall Credit One is a growing company with great culture and people.

summary: Good for a short time not a long time (not a great place to grow through your career)
pros:
� decent pay for the area
� decent benefits 
� stable job
� good people
cons:
� you will never get promoted
� seems like senior management doesn�t care about employees 
� subpar work life balance in comparison with others

pros: Very stable, well run company. This company makes good decisions and avoids financial crises and layoffs. Cautious approach pays off in long run. Good work-life balance - you take your work home, your time is your time.
cons: Not hybrid work. Not the most innovative place - strategies are stable and slow to develop. Because of company stability, advancement can sometimes be up to turnover, which is currently low.

summary: Good people, less than good messaging
pros: The people and environment are friendly depending on your department and team. Stable work, except they did lay off a ton of IT this year. Office is nice, but cafeteria literally hasn�t been functional for 3 years.
cons:
Senior management and HR is out of touch and contradictory. 
We had a department wide meeting discussing the employee survey and Glassdoor reviews in relation to other companies in our industry. We gloat that we are the best and the leader in our field. ALL other companies offer hybrid minimum. We actively compare ourselves to other companies to set our standards (salary, scheduling, holidays). Keep this in mind for the rest of the review. All these quotes came from senior management during this meeting regarding employee feedback via survey and Glassdoor.
�If you want hybrid, you need to do some soul searching�. However, when called out that we never seen them in office or �on the floor� they say �We are senior management. We are trust worthy, so we can work from home�. Alright. You don�t trust the employees then? 
There are complaints about not having certain holidays off. �We check other companies to see if enough of them take a holiday off. If it passes a threshold, we add it as a holiday�. We are suppose to be industry LEADERS and we can�t even give Veterans Day off unless other SMALLER companies do it first? 
All other smaller companies in our space are doing work from home, let�s follow that threshold and follow suit then! Make it make sense. 
�Senior management sees value in everyone working here, that�s why we didn�t just hire some offshore workers�. Gee thanks, that�s super nice to hear as a human being. Thank you for not outsourcing me. There are complaints about lack of promotion and career progression. �If turnover is higher, you have a higher chance of promotion�. Wow, we love retaining top talent right? By building a toxic work environment where we hope our coworkers leave so we have the slim chance of promotion. What we got from the employee survey response was 
1. We heard you, and don�t care
2. We don�t trust you to do your job
3. Promotions will not happen unless you cannibalize your coworkers
4. We compare our industry standards when it agrees with senior management, but if it doesn�t, let�s ignore the rest of the industry standards.
I know the response on here will say �just leave if you aren�t happy�. I get it. But also, employees are told to provide feedback in hopes of making a change to their workplace. What if I want to make my current workplace better? Does the employee voice not matter? What�s the point of the survey if everything is dismissed immediately? Do you not want people to stay? 
�We are not in the business of human suffering� said HR.
Okay, then let�s listen to your workers who put in effort everyday to make the company successful.

summary: Inspiring Leaders, Great Opportunities and Resources
pros: While i wont be able to assess the entire company, based on my experiences in Risk. My tenure at the bank has been a positive one. The benefits of working in an employer of this size is that you are valued for your inputs on new projects and visions for the bank. Projects are rewarding as you feel your inputs are valued as an employee. There are controls but is not extensive to the point where work is difficult to complete. Pay structure is competitive with the overall market. Whether it is someone just joining or others that are more tenured in their profession, C1B remains a great place to work. Again, this is based on my time at RISK. Work life balance is great. benefits are competitive. 401k match is competitive. Great People!
cons: Promotion needs to be collectively agreed upon by multiple leaders. Leaders would influence tremendously as far as which teams are allocated resources. Others have expressed issues with WFH. Maternity and Paternity Leave of absence is less than other banks.

pros:
Stable, well performing company
Job security
cons:
Different rules for different departments - several teams at C1B work from home but everyone pretends like it isn�t happening 

No incentives for performance

Zero paternity leave

pros: Good to newbies getting into corporate work out of college/transitioning
cons: Lots of remote workers, not enough qa, not enough collaboration

pros: Tickets to VGK and Raiders games.
cons: They took away the kitchen. Nepotism is very high. Sexism. Blatant retaliation. High turn over. Incompetent employees at all levels including management that was hired or promoted due to nepotism. Lower than the national average for salaries. No paternity leave. A lot of "Good ol boys". Leadership taking advantage of employees with work visas. Can be easily promoted due to turn over, but the issues is then put on you instead of being resolved and you wind up doing 3 peoples jobs.

pros: The team I am working is super, I like the people. The manager is very understanding as well.
cons: The salary increases and position growth is hard to obtain.

summary: Great place to work in Las Vegas
pros: Really nice campus. Strong business in all economic environments - don't have to worry about layoffs in recessions/COVID/2007-2009 crash, etc. A true meritocracy. If you work hard and deliver you will be rewarded. If you do just enough to get by, you will not. If you have an unhealthy sense of entitlement, you'll put this criteria in the cons section, but it's a pro for me.
cons: No corporation is perfect, and Credit One has it's issues like all other workplaces, but I believe the good outweighs the bad. Historically siloed org structure where interdepartmental collaboration was poor. Luckily this is getting substantially better in recent years with executive regime changes and retirements. I question the decision to get rid of the cafeteria and think the company should consider bringing it back. I'd prefer if cable news was banned from TVs in the building, the workplace should be void of left & right wing propoganda.

summary: A good company to work for in Las Vegas valley
pros:
Good work life balance
Challenging problems
cons:
Less competition 
Food is not served in cafeteria

summary: Get your foot in the door, then get out.
pros:
From a software engineer's perspective this is an excellent place to 'validate' your career and get started fresh out of college or if you're newly transitioning in to the field.

Other notable qualities include:
- Very clean office space located immediately off of the freeway

- Most people you'll run in to are friendly and collaborative

- Health, Medical, 401k, etc.

- Personal development scenarios such as taking classes or getting certifications are compensated

- Managers are aware the company pays below industry standards so they've made their interview processes much easier for technical roles.
cons:
Some of which include:
- No remote capabilities, you'll drive in to the office and join a teams call for 9/10 of your meetings.

- Your performance is irrelevant and there's little to no incentive to work hard. Your best chance at earning a promotion is by negotiating an offer letter from a new company or going to a new company after 6-12 months.

- From a software engineering standpoint the work will feel challenging, but not rewarding. The company utilizes older versions of enterprise software that will give you very little transferable knowledge. You will need to block out time for yourself and build upon your own personal development if you want individual growth.

- Severe lack of faith in senior management is widespread especially within technical positions.

- Company pays far below the standard for many of their positions, and in doing so the talent pool is smaller and turnover is much higher.

- Minimal flexibility in your role and in most cases you will be taking an endless stream of tickets

- Cross-team collaboration is laughably poor.

pros: there is nothing to do there
cons: you don't learn anything new

summary: Great People, Enjoyable Work, No WFH
pros: I work with some amazing people and truly enjoy the work I do every day. It is challenging, but interesting and I enjoy solving the problems we face.
cons: My job could be 100% remote, but we do not have that option. Additionally, I am underpaid relative to the amount of work I do and expertise I provide.

summary: An unhealthy mix of toxicity and mediocrity
pros: With low expectations, it's easy to stand out and get promoted. The business is growing and profitable, so there is good job stability. The people are great to work with at the mid-lower levels. It's a good place to start a career and then get out.
cons: I can almost guarantee you won't find a culture worse than Credit One. Very little flexibility, toxic meetings and interactions with senior management, below average pay, no stock packages, outdated benefits, poorly trained managers, politics are crazy and drive most decisions, dinosaur tech, inflated egos running rampant, and most employees that I interacted with are miserable and just biding their time until something better comes along.

pros: Good to learn about finance and early careers
cons: In-person office. No remote or hybrid work culture.

pros:
There are so many pros for working at Credit One Bank. There is breakfast/snacks free for the employees every single morning. The benefits are amazing and available almost immediately after you start. The bosses that I have are amazing. 

This is the one and only job that I have ever loved so much and enjoy going to work everyday. I see my colleagues smiling and always happy and have never really seen an unhappy co-worker. 

#1 place for me to work.
cons: The only con I have is the 5 minute walk to my car. Huge parking lot and can�t park in the reserved parking spots. I look at it as getting my steps in daily. Other than that I have no other cons.

pros: Great place to work for
cons: everything is great so far

pros: Free snacks, holidays (some not all) are paid and off work
cons: Low pay for the expectations, you are expected to stay longer than expected to �complete� work, lots of mindless meetings that serve no purpose, �provide� for your advancement however they won�t compensate you a fair market value unless you come from the outside, employees are not treated fairly for the same role

summary: Steady/Boring - The epitome of a mediocre workplace
pros: Stable job with ok base pay and pretty good benefits. If you are moderately capable, you'll have a job here forever. That's worth a lot.
cons:
It's a boring, single product-line bank (credit cards). Never going to be anything splashy or spectacular, never going to be an exciting place to work or on the forefront of industry innovation.

Managerial incompetence is largely tolerated, as to avoid difficult conversations, especially at senior levels.

Mediocre performers get the same pay as top performers. Leadership is concerned with not paying anyone too much, other than the CEO, rather than paying top performers for what they bring to the table. The company has fantastic financial performance every year, but doesn't share that equitably with employees.

Too few holidays, no hybrid flexibility (full-time in office).

None of the above will change anytime soon.

pros: Depending on the team you land on the work life balance is really good. Pay is not too bad although it could be better. Going through some technological revamping that should bring the companies way of doing things a bit more up to date.
cons: They start some people at lower levels than they should start and some at higher levels than they should start so it is a bit of a crap shoot getting into the right starting position. Having a lot of education and data skills certainly helps.

summary: Prepare for a Masterclass on how to demoralize employees.
pros: There are zero reasons to work at Credit One Bank unless you are absolutely desperate for a job.
cons:
Terrible leadership (stand down) that engages in mental gymnastics to explain away horrendous employee satisfaction scores (stand down). How do I know this? Nearly 30 people either quit or moved to other departments since the beginning of 2022 to avoid working with the leaders overseeing our department. 

The bank engages in predatory practices that take advantage of an already disadvantaged group of people looking for credit. 

My advice? Stand down and run...run as far away from this place as you possibly can. Leadership makes too much money to care about their employees well-being or happiness while they work in the prison they call an office building.

summary: Good but has scope of improvement
pros:
1. Great company to kickstart your career.
2. Gives opportunities to people from all kind of career background.
3. Not much work pressure and easily manageable. 
4. 3 weeks of vacation holidays and 2 weeks of Sick leave.
cons:
1. Leaderships do not encourage to explore cutting edge technology, mostly because financial industry is highly regulated.
2. No work from home option.
3. Salary is lesser than other financial banks.
4. Vacation hours and sick leave needs to be accrued. 
5.  Other than the paid leaves, there is very limited holidays given to the employees. Most of the federal holidays are not celebrated. No holiday in the Dec other than 25th Dec and 1st Jan. Thanksgiving holiday is just one day. For god's sake please give 2 days for Thanksgiving.

pros: There are no pros at this place.
cons: low pay to work in a soul crushing office with inconsiderate people that will annoy you and get you and your family sick. There is virtually no investment in official training courses outside of a udemy account. GL. Low pay and they expect you to continue working at home to learn on your own. No work life balance. Just work because you are a sub human cog in the corporate machine. Tens of billions of dollars in profit aren't enough for this bank. 99% uptime isn't enough for this bank. Unfathomable corporate greed and unrealistic expectations is all you will see here. Forget about any remote work opportunities as well. They want to control every facet of your life.
